statement.p: List the elements of the following sets. If there is more than one element write them separated by commas.
Let S = \lbrace w,x,y,z\rbrace, T = \lbrace 0\rbrace
How many elements are in S\times T?
Determine S\times T
[Note: Enter your answer as a comma-separated list. Pairs should be denoted with parentheses.]

static.solution:
S = \lbrace w,x,y,z\rbrace
T = \lbrace 0\rbrace
The number of elements in a Cartesian product is simply N(A)\cdot N(B) for any sets A, B.
Thus, the number of elements in S\times T is
N(A)\cdot N(B) = 4\cdot 1 = 4
The Cartesian product A\times B is defined as the set of all ordered pairs whose first component is a member of A and whose second component is a member of B.
More formally, A\times B = \lbrace (a,b) \vert a\in A \textbf{ and } b\in B\rbrace
Thus, S\times T is
\lbrace (w,0),(x,0),(y,0),(z,0)\rbrace

statement.p: Let f(x) = x^{2}. Find each set.

static.solution: x^{2} is not one-to-one, you can not simply plug the endpoints of the interval into the function to get the endpoints of the answer. Instead, try graphing the function and shading on the x-axis the input set. Then use the graph to see which y-values you get out when you put those x's in. For instance, notice that 0 \in (-4, 5). Because f(0) = 0, you should have 0 \in f( (-4, 5)). Do you?

statement.p: For each of the following functions, f:\textbf{R}\longrightarrow\textbf{R} state whether they are one-to-one, onto, both or neither. Use the following key:

Consider the functions f(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x}{4}} + 8, g(x) = -8 + 4 x^{7}, h(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x}{4}} - 8, p(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x - 8}{4}}, q(x) = 8 + 4 x^{7}, and r(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x + 8}{4}}.
Which of these functions are inverses of each other?

li.p: p(x) and q(x)
g(x) and p(x)
f(x) and q(x)
h(x) and q(x)
g(x) and h(x)
q(x) and r(x)
g(x) and r(x)
f(x) and g(x)
No pairs of these functions are inverses of each other.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
One way we can check which functions are inverses is to make sure they satisfy the identities f \left( f^{-1}(x) \right)=x and f^{-1} \left( f(x) \right)=x. This will show that p(x) and q(x) and g(x) and r(x) are inverses of each other, while the other pairs of functions are not.
Let's consider p(x) and q(x). The composition \begin{aligned} p\left(q(x)\right) \amp = 8 + 4 \left(\sqrt[7]{ \frac{x - 8}{4}}\right)^{7} \\ \amp = 8 + 4 \left( \frac{x - 8}{4} \right) \\ \amp = 8 + (x-8) = x. \end{aligned} Also, \begin{aligned} q\left(p(x)\right) \amp = \sqrt[7]{\frac{\left( 8+4 x^{7} \right)-8}{4}} \\ \amp = \sqrt[7]{x^{7}} = x. \end{aligned} Thus these are inverses of one another. We can similarly show that g(x) and r(x) are inverses of each other.
However, the remaining pairs are not inverses. For example, if we consider q(x) and r(x), we have \begin{aligned} q\left(r(x)\right) \amp = 8 + 4 \left( \sqrt[7]{ \frac{x + 8}{4}} \right)^{7}\\ \amp = 8 + (x+8) = x + 16 \ne x. \end{aligned} Thus these functions are not inverses of each other.

statement.p: Assign truth values to the propositions P, Q, and R so that the given proposition is false. Use T for true and F for false.
Answer: P: Q: R:
Determine the truth value of the following statements if the universe of discourse is the set of real numbers.

Let C(x) be the statement "x has a cat", let D(x) be the statement "x has a dog" and let F(x) be the statement "xhas a ferret". Express each of the following statements in terms of C(x), D(x), and F(x), quantifiers, and logical connectives. Let the universe of discourse consist of all students in your class. Put the appropriate letter next to the corresponding symbolic form.
a) A student in your class has a cat, a dog, and a ferret.
b) All students in your class have a cat, a dog, or a ferret.
c) Some student in your class has a cat and a ferret but not a dog.
d) No student in this class has a cat, a dog, and a ferret.
e) For each of the three animals, cats, dogs, and ferrets, there is a student in your class who has one of these animals.

Let P(x) be the statement "x is a duck", let Q(x) be the statement "x is one of my poultry", let R(x) be the statement "x is an officer", and let S(x) be the statement "x is willing to waltz". Express each of the following statements in terms of P(x), Q(x), R(x) and S(x), quantifiers, and logical connectives. Let the universe of discourse consist of all living creatures. Put the appropriate letter next to the corresponding symbolic form.
a) Some ducks are not willing to waltz.
b) No ducks are willing to waltz.
c) No officers ever decline to waltz.
d) All my poultry are ducks.
e) My poultry are not officers.
Determine whether the given proposition is true or false, for the universe of all real numbers. Use T for true and F for false.
Answer:
Answer:
Answer:
Answer:
Answer:

Determine whether the following system has no solution, an infinite number of solutions or a unique solution.

p.m: \left\lbrace\begin{array}{rllrrr} -8 x \amp - 7 y \amp = \amp 3 \cr 4 x \amp + 4 y \amp = \amp 8 \cr -16 x \amp - 13 y \amp = \amp 25 \end{array} \right.

Find the set of solutions for the linear system

\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} x_1 \amp + \amp 4 x_{2} \amp + \amp 6 x_{3} \amp = \amp -10 \\ \amp - \amp x_{2} \amp - \amp 4 x_{3} \amp = \amp -9 \\ \amp \amp \amp \amp 3 x_{3} \amp = \amp 9\end{array} Use s1, s2, etc. for the free variables if necessary.

solution.p: SOLUTION: Equation 3 \Rightarrow x_3 = 3. Substitute into equation 2, -x_2 - 4(3) = -9 \Rightarrow x_2 = -3. Substitute into equation 1, x_1 + 4(-3) + 6(3) = -10 \Rightarrow x_1 = -16.

Note: In part (f), if there are no solutions, write "No Solution" or "None" in the answer blank after each equal sign. If there are infinitely many solutions, and the solution set describes a line (that is, if there is only one free variable), set x_{3} = t and solve for the remaining variables in terms of t. If there are infinitely many solutions, and the solution set describes a plane (that is, if the solution set has two free variables), set the variables x_3 = t and x_2 = s, and then solve for x_1 in terms of s and t.

li.p: If \displaystyle A and \displaystyle B are square matrices of the same size then \displaystyle (A+B)^2 = A^2 + 2AB + B^2.
If \displaystyle A and \displaystyle B are matrices such that \displaystyle AB = O and \displaystyle A \neq O, then \displaystyle B = O.

The matrices \displaystyle A^TA and \displaystyle AA^T are always defined, regardless of the size of \displaystyle A.
If \displaystyle A is a square matrix for which \displaystyle A^2 = A, then either \displaystyle A = I or \displaystyle A = O.

If A and B are invertible n\times n matrices, then the inverse of A+B is A^{-1}+B^{-1}.
True
False

solution.p: SOLUTION: False. For example, let A = I_n, and B = -I_n, then A+B = 0_n, which is not invertible.

statement.p: Solve for the matrix X if AX(D+B X)^{-1} = C. Assume that all matrices are n\times n and invertible as needed.

solution.p: SOLUTION: Note that \begin{align*} AX(D+BX)^{-1} = C \amp \Rightarrow AX = C(D+BX) = CD + CBX \\ \amp \Rightarrow AX - CBX = CD\\ \amp \Rightarrow (A-CB)X = CD \\ \amp \Rightarrow X = (A-CB)^{-1} CD. \end{align*}

statement.p: Are the following matrices invertible?

solution.p:
SOLUTION: The matrix \displaystyle A =  egin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 1 \ c \amp c^2 \end{bmatrix} is invertible provided the columns of A are linearly independent, which will be the case if c 
eq c^2. Thus, we require that c
eq 0 and c 
eq 1.

True or false: Suppose that E_1 and E_2 are two elementary matrices. Then E_1E_2 = E_2E_1
.
True
False

solution.p: SOLUTION: False. If E_1 = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0\cr 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \quad \mbox{and} \quad E_2 = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right], then E_1 E_2 = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0\cr 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1\cr 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right], but E_2 E_1 = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0\cr 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 1\cr 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \neq E_1 E_2.

Let \mathbf{u}_4 be a linear combination of \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3\rbrace.
Select the best statement.

li.p: We only know that \mathrm{span} \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3 \rbrace\subseteq \mathrm{span} \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3, \mathbf{u}_4\rbrace .
There is no obvious relationship between \mathrm{span} \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3 \rbrace and \mathrm{span} \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3, \mathbf{u}_4 \rbrace .
\mathrm{span}\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3 \rbrace = \mathrm{span}\lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3, \mathbf{u}_4 \rbrace .

\mathrm{span} \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3 \rbrace= \mathrm{span} \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3, \mathbf{u}_4\rbrace when \mathbf{u}_4 is a scalar multiple of one of \lbrace\mathbf{u}_1,\mathbf{u}_2,\mathbf{u}_3 \rbrace.
none of the above

static.solution: \left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3\right\rbrace= span\left\lbrace{\bf u}_1,{\bf u}_2,{\bf u}_3,{\bf u}_4\right\rbrace.

none of the above

{\bf u}_4 is a linear combination of \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3}\rbrace then \lbrace{{\bf u}_1, {\bf u}_2, {\bf u}_3, {\bf u}_4}\rbrace is linearly dependent. Otherwise the set in linearly independent.

Are the following statements true or false?

li.p: Let m\lt n. Then U = {u_1, u_2,\ldots, u_m} in R^n can form a basis for R^n if the correct n-m vectors are added to U.
If \ S_1 is of dimension 3 and is a subspace of R^4, then there can not exist a subspaceS_2 of R^4 such that S_1 \subset S_2 \subset R^4 with S_1 \ne S_2 and S_2 \ne R^4.
The set {0} forms a basis for the zero subspace.
Let m>n. Then U = {u_1, u_2,\ldots, u_m} in R^n can form a basis for R^n if the correct m-n vectors are removed from U.
R^n has exactly one subspace of dimension m for each of m = 0,1,2,\ldots, n .

statement.p: Suppose that S_1 and S_2 are nonzero subspaces, with S_1 contained inside S_2, and suppose that dim(S_2) = 3.

(a) What are the possible dimensions of S_1?
?
1
2
3
1 or 2
1,2, or 3

(b) If S_1\neq S_2 then what are the possible dimensions of S_1?
?
1
2
3
1 or 2
1,2, or 3

static.solution:
(a) The dimension of S_1 cannot exceed the dimension of S_2 since S_1 is contained in S_2. S_1 is non-zero, and thus its dimension cannot be 0. Hence 1, 2, or 3 are the possible dimensions of S_1.
(b) If S_1 \ne S_2, then S_1 is properly contained in S_2, and the dimension of S_1 is strictly less than the dimension of S_2. Thus only 1 or 2 are possible dimensions of S_1 .

statement.p: Suppose that S_1 and S_2 are nonzero subspaces, with S_1 contained inside S_2, and suppose that dim(S_2) = 4

li.p: What are the possible dimensions of S_1?
If \ S_1 \ne S_2, then what are the possible dimensions of S_1 ?

static.solution:
S_1 cannot exceed the dimension of S_2, since S_1 is contained in S_2. S_1 us non-zero, and thus the its dimension cannot be zero. Hence the possible dimensions of S_1 are 1, 2, 3, and 4.
b) If S_1 \ne S_2, then S_1 is properly contained in S_2, and the dimension of S_1 is strictly less than the dimension of S_2. So the possible dimensions of S_1 are 1, 2, and 3.

statement.p: By deleting linearly dependent vectors, find a basis of each subspace and give the dimension of the subspace.

Suppose that A is a 5 \times 8 matrix that has an echelon form with one zero row. Find the dimension of the row space of A, the dimension of the column space of A, and the dimension of the null space of A.
The dimension of the row space of A is .
The dimension of the column space of A is .
The dimension of the null space of A is .

solution.p: The dimension of the row space is the number of nonzero rows in the echelon form, or 5 - 1 = 4. The dimension of the column space is the same as the dimension of the row space, and the dimension of the null space is 8 - 4 = 4.

statement.p: Are the following statements true or false?

li.p: Let m>n. Then U = {u_1, u_2,\ldots, u_m} in R^n can form a basis for R^n if the correct m-n vectors are removed from U.
The nullity of a matrix A is the same as the dimension of the subspace spanned be the columns of A.
If {u_1, u_2, u_3} is a basis for R^3, then span{u_1, u_2} is a plane.
If \ S_1 is of dimension 3 and is a subspace of R^4, then there can not exist a subspaceS_2 of R^4 such that S_1 \subset S_2 \subset R^4 with S_1 \ne S_2 and S_2 \ne R^4.
R^n has exactly one subspace of dimension m for each of m = 0,1,2,\ldots, n .

statement.p: Are the following statements true or false?

li.p: If the set of vectors U is linearly independent in a subspace S then vectors can be added to U to create a basis for S
If \ S_1 and \ S_2 are subspaces of R^n of the same dimension, then S_1=S_2.
If the set of vectors U is linearly independent in a subspace S then vectors can be removed from U to create a basis for S.
If \ S = span{u_1, u_2, u_3}, then dim(S) = 3 .
Three nonzero vectors that lie in a plane in R^3 might form a basis for R^3.

statement.p: Let A = \left[\begin{array}{cccc} -3 \amp -3 \amp -9 \amp 0\cr -3 \amp -4 \amp -10 \amp 2\cr -6 \amp -7 \amp -19 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]. Find dimensions of the kernel and image of T(\vec{x}) = A \vec{x}.
{\rm dim } ({\rm Ker } (A)) = ,
{\rm dim } ({\rm Im } (A)) = .

Let f : \mathbb{R}^{3} \to \mathbb{R}^{2} be the linear transformation defined by f(x,y,z) = \left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 2 \end{array}\right] x + \left[\begin{array}{c} 3\cr -5 \end{array}\right] y + \left[\begin{array}{c} -16\cr 28 \end{array}\right] z. Find bases for the kernel and image of f. vector
A basis for the kernel of f is \Big\lbrace \Big\rbrace.
A basis for the image of f is \Big\lbrace \Big\rbrace.
Let L:\mathbb{R}^3 \to \mathbb{R}^3 be the linear operator defined by

p.me: L(x) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 12 x_1 + 36 x_2 - 12 x_3\\ 18 x_2\\ 36 x_1 - 36 x_3 \end{array}\right]

statement.p: (a) Find the dimension of the range of L:
(b) Find the dimension of the kernel of L:
(c) Let S be the subspace of \mathbb{R}^3 spanned by -2 e_1 and 10 e_2 + 10 e_3. Find the dimension of L(S):

solution.p: Solution: (a) Since e_1, e_2, e_3 spans \mathbb{R}^3, we get that L(\mathbb{R}^3) is spanned by L(e_1), L(e_2), L(e_3). So
and hence the dimension of the range is 2.
(b) The rank-nullity theorem implies that the dimension of the kernel is 3-2 = 1.
(c) Notice that L(S) = \mbox{span}\left(L(-2 e_1), L(10 e_2 + 10 e_3)\right) = \mbox{span}\left(L(e_1), L(e_2)+L(e_3)\right)
and it is easy to check that these two vectors are linearly independent. Therefore, the dimension of L(S) is 2.
